headline: Trump's call for a 10% credit card rate cap is 'inconceivable'
summary: Trump called on Congress to implement a 10% cap on credit card interest rates, but Wolfe Research head of US policy and politics Tobin Marcus says that the odds of the cap coming to fruition are "essentially zero," highlighting unintended consequences for consumers. Marcus tells Market Catalysts Host Julie Hyman that some of the other affordability-focused efforts that Trump has called for — like banning large institutional investors from buying single-family homes — and the Credit Card Competition Act are unlikely, but not "inconceivable" like the credit card rate cap. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: Branch and Mastercard® Research Finds Shifting Career Priorities, New Technology Fueling a Solopreneur Boom
